content: Airline passenger screening in the United States has evolved significantly post-9/11 with new technologies and policy changes overseen by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) created under the Aviation Transportation and Security Act (ATSA). The Aviation Transportation and Security Act (ATSA; P.L. 107-71) mandated TSA to provide comprehensive security screening for all airline passengers and property. Congress also allowed TSA to implement trusted traveler programs and use technology to expedite screening, focusing on passengers needing more extensive checks. Subsequently, Congress directed TSA to check all passengers against terrorist watchlists. The TSA has primarily relied on a uniform risk assumption for airport checkpoint screening, unlike its risk-based strategies for other aspects of aviation security. This approach has led to challenges in improving screening capabilities, with a focus on technology such as whole-body imagers and advanced X-ray equipment. The TSA has focused on technology such as whole-body imagers and advanced X-ray equipment to improve detection of threat objects at airport checkpoints. However, constraints like technology limitations, budgetary considerations, and limited resources have hindered a solely technology-driven approach. TSA personnel face challenges in screening passengers efficiently due to time and resource constraints, as well as limitations on screener hiring and space at airports. The TSA has focused on improving airport security by adding screening lanes and personnel, but passengers still face cumbersome procedures like removing shoes and separating laptops for X-ray screening. This has led to unpredictable wait times and criticism from experts, including former TSA Administrator Kip Hawley. The TSA has shifted to a risk-based screening approach in response to criticisms about the security system being brittle. This shift has sparked controversy over how to assess and mitigate security risks, with differing views on where security efforts should be focused.
